description:
Dengue virus type 1 (DENV-1) is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus that belongs to the Flavivirus genus within the Flaviviridae family. It is one of the four main serotypes of the dengue virus (DENV-1, DENV-2, DENV-3, and DENV-4), which are the causative agents of dengue fever, a mosquito-borne viral disease.

DENV-1 is primarily transmitted to humans through the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes, which serve as the primary vectors for the virus. Upon entry into the human host, the virus targets and infects various cell types, including dendritic cells, monocytes, and hepatocytes, leading to the development of clinical symptoms associated with dengue fever.

The DENV-1 genome consists of approximately 10,700 nucleotides and encodes a single polyprotein that is subsequently cleaved into three structural proteins (capsid, pre-membrane, and envelope) and seven non-structural proteins (NS1, NS2A, NS2B, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, and NS5). These proteins play crucial roles in viral replication, assembly, and immune evasion.

Infection with DENV-1 can result in a range of clinical manifestations, from mild flu-like symptoms to more severe forms of the disease, such as dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome. The severity of the illness can depend on factors such as the individual's immune status, previous exposure to dengue viruses, and the circulating viral genotype.

Effective prevention and control of DENV-1 infections rely on integrated strategies, including vector control measures, early diagnosis, and the development of safe and effective vaccines. Ongoing research aims to better understand the molecular mechanisms underlying DENV-1 pathogenesis and to explore new therapeutic approaches to combat this significant public health concern.
